sections.title: Introduction
sections.summary: Introduction to the chapter's topics including Euclid's division algorithm and the Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic, with an overview of their applications in exploring properties of real numbers.

keyConcepts.name: Real Numbers
keyConcepts.description: The set of all rational and irrational numbers that form the complete number system.

keyConcepts.name: Euclid's Division Algorithm
keyConcepts.description: A method describing how any positive integer can be divided by another positive integer leaving a remainder smaller than the divisor.

keyConcepts.name: Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic
keyConcepts.description: The principle that every composite number can be expressed as a unique product of prime numbers, apart from the order of factors.

sections.title: The Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic
sections.summary: This section formally introduces the Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic, which states that every composite number can be uniquely factorized as a product of primes, and explores its applications.

keyConcepts.name: Prime Number
keyConcepts.description: A natural number greater than 1 that is only divisible by 1 and itself.

keyConcepts.name: Composite Number
keyConcepts.description: A natural number greater than 1 that can be formed by multiplying smaller natural numbers.

keyConcepts.name: Prime Factorization
keyConcepts.description: The process of expressing a composite number as a product of prime numbers.
keyConcepts.notation: Usually written with prime factors in ascending order with powers: e.g., 32760 = 2³ × 3² × 5 × 7 × 13

keyConcepts.name: Uniqueness of Prime Factorization
keyConcepts.description: The fact that the prime factorization of any number is unique except for the order of factors.

visualElements.description: Illustration of the prime factorization of 32760 using a factor tree diagram.
visualElements.interactivityHint: Students could create their own factor trees for different numbers.

theorems.statement: Every composite number can be expressed (factorized) as a product of primes, and this factorization is unique, apart from the order in which the prime factors occur.
theorems.explanation: This fundamental theorem provides the basis for many applications in number theory.
theorems.proof: Attributed to Carl Friedrich Gauss in his Disquisitiones Arithmeticae.

examples.content: Factor tree for 32760 showing factorization as 2³ × 3² × 5 × 7 × 13
examples.context: Demonstrating the prime factorization process for a large number.

examples.content: Consider the numbers 4ⁿ, where n is a natural number. Check whether there is any value of n for which 4ⁿ ends with the digit zero.
examples.context: Using the Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic to analyze divisibility by 5.

examples.content: Finding HCF and LCM of 6 and 20 using prime factorization: HCF = 2, LCM = 60
examples.context: Practical application of prime factorization to find HCF and LCM.

examples.content: Finding HCF of 96 and 404 as 4, and LCM as 9696 using the formula LCM = (a×b)/HCF
examples.context: Another example of using prime factorization for HCF and LCM.

examples.content: Finding HCF and LCM of 6, 72, and 120 as 6 and 360 respectively
examples.context: Extending the method to three numbers.

exercises.skillTargeted: Using the Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic for divisibility

sections.title: Revisiting Irrational Numbers
sections.summary: This section proves the irrationality of square roots of prime numbers, particularly √2, √3, and √5, using the Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic.

keyConcepts.name: Irrational Number
keyConcepts.description: A real number that cannot be expressed as p/q where p and q are integers and q ≠ 0.

keyConcepts.name: Proof by Contradiction
keyConcepts.description: A method of mathematical proof where we assume the opposite of what we want to prove and show it leads to a contradiction.

theorems.statement: Let p be a prime number. If p divides a², then p divides a, where a is a positive integer.
theorems.explanation: This theorem helps prove the irrationality of square roots of prime numbers.
This means √2 cannot be expressed as a ratio of integers.
theorems.proof: Uses proof by contradiction and the Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic.

theorems.explanation: Similar to the proof for √2, this shows √3 cannot be expressed as a ratio of integers.

examples.content: Proof that √2 is irrational using proof by contradiction and the Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic
examples.context: Demonstrating how to prove irrationality using these theorems.
Similar approach to prove another irrational number.
Proving that the sum or difference of a rational and an irrational number is irrational.
Demonstrating that the product of a non-zero rational and an irrational number is irrational.

exercises.problem: Prove that 1/√2, 7√5, and 6 + √2 are irrational numbers.

keyVocabulary.definition: A natural number greater than 1 that is only divisible by 1 and itself.
A natural number greater than 1 that is not prime and can be formed by multiplying smaller natural numbers.
Highest Common Factor - the largest positive integer that divides each of the given integers.
Least Common Multiple - the smallest positive integer that is divisible by each of the given integers.
A real number that cannot be expressed as a ratio of integers.
For positive integers a and b, there exist unique integers q and r such that a = bq + r, where 0 ≤ r < b.
The process of decomposing a composite number into a product of prime numbers.

commonMisconceptions.misconception: HCF(p, q, r) × LCM(p, q, r) = p × q × r for three numbers
commonMisconceptions.correction: While HCF(a,b) × LCM(a,b) = a × b for two numbers, this property doesn't extend directly to three or more numbers.
Square roots of perfect squares (like √4, √9) are rational, while square roots of non-perfect squares are irrational.

commonMisconceptions.misconception: Prime factorization is always easy to find
commonMisconceptions.correction: For very large numbers, finding the prime factorization can be computationally difficult, which is the basis for some cryptographic systems.

assessmentIdeas.question: Express 5005 as a product of its prime factors.
Prove that √5 is irrational.
assessmentIdeas.answer: Use proof by contradiction, assuming √5 = a/b where a and b are coprime, and show this leads to a contradiction.

assessmentIdeas.question: Find the LCM and HCF of 336 and 54, and verify that LCM × HCF = product of the two numbers.
Two people take 18 minutes and 12 minutes respectively to complete one round of a circular path. If they start together, how many minutes later will they meet again at the starting point?
assessmentIdeas.answer: Using LCM(18, 12) = 36, they will meet after 36 minutes.

personalities.name: Carl Friedrich Gauss
personalities.description: Amazon Web Services (AWS) is a comprehensive and widely adopted cloud computing platform provided by Amazon. It offers a broad range of on-demand services such as computing power, storage, databases, networking, analytics, machine learning, artificial intelligence, Internet of Things (IoT), mobile services, and security. Launched in 2006, AWS enables individuals, businesses, and governments to scale and grow without the need to invest heavily in physical IT infrastructure. AWS operates on a global scale with data centers located in multiple regions and availability zones, ensuring high availability, redundancy, and low-latency performance for applications. The platform is based on a pay-as-you-go pricing model, which means customers only pay for the resources they use, making it cost-effective and flexible. Some of the most popular AWS services include Amazon EC2 (Elastic Compute Cloud) for scalable computing power, Amazon S3 (Simple Storage Service) for object storage, Amazon RDS (Relational Database Service) for managed databases, AWS Lambda for serverless computing, and Amazon CloudFront for content delivery. AWS is used by startups, enterprises, and public sector organizations across the globe for diverse workloads, including hosting websites, running enterprise applications, data analytics, machine learning model deployment, and disaster recovery solutions. The platform also offers strong security and compliance features, meeting global regulatory requirements. With its constant innovation, wide service portfolio, and strong reliability, AWS has established itself as a leader in the cloud computing industry.

mathematicalHeritage.historicalContext: The Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic was first recorded as Proposition 14 of Book IX in Euclid's Elements, but the first correct proof was given by Carl Friedrich Gauss.
indianContributions: Ancient Indian mathematicians made significant contributions to number theory
mathematicalHeritage.culturalSignificance: Number theory has been studied across cultures for thousands of years and forms the foundation of modern cryptography and computing.
